07D98A15334C46CF9A1A00C487C1CDDA.description: LA12.E.41: acquire and use accurately general academic and domain-specific words and phrases, sufficient for reading, writing, speaking, and listening at the college and career readiness level; demonstrate independence in gathering vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression

4B9D9D5BC48347838F4684C1EEAC401B.description: LA12.E.40.b: analyze nuances in the meaning of words with similar denotations

91C06D27FD6A4C82B5628E44B5E6B864.description: LA12.E.40.a: interpret figures of speech (e.g., hyperbole, paradox) in context and analyze their role in the text

4E3719A9ADBF4DEF866B1F011E5F8848.description: LA12.E.40: demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings

C7DB678452954B96AB387608D8118B80.description: LA12.E.39.e: verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a word or phrase (e.g., by checking the inferred meaning in context or in a dictionary)

106FC3C16EF540CDBAD2AE7E67CC177E.description: LA12.E.39.d: consult general and specialized reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its precise meaning, its part of speech, its etymology, or its standard usage

4A5A4511CC524A19A495A7F4F5DB1A9E.description: LA12.E.39.c: identify and correctly use patterns of word changes that indicate different meanings or parts of speech (e.g., conceive, conception, conceivable)

9E12FB783F1D4BB48A356E90EBBCA8C7.description: LA12.E.39.b: use common, grade-appropriate Greek and Latin roots as clues to the meanings of words or phrases (e.g., colloquial, elocution, eloquent)

3FA37B91D9914E13A97B67241011A69F.description: LA12.E.39.a: use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence, paragraph, or text; a word's position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase

4ECD8EC30D6946508E23FBE1B68A58D3.description: LA12.E.39: determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grades 11-12 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies

267E10207F244217B8B34F779911BFA4.description: LA12.E.38.a: vary syntax for effect, consulting references (e.g., Tufte's Artful Sentences) for guidance as needed; apply an understanding of syntax to the study of complex texts when reading

9A6C6A9E81FF4DB7A333025C5BDBEC93.description: LA12.E.38: apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening

1DB6BD8DC5434C5D9DF718F7077AFBBF.description: LA12.E.37: demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing

3ABF1658CD594CDF83A2314C3291BD97.description: LA12.E.36.b: resolve issues of complex or contested usage, consulting references (e.g., Merriam-Webster's Dictionary of English Usage, Garner's Modern American Usage) as needed

FA6FBC0E13C542C783085060165A8F5A.description: LA12.E.36.a: apply the understanding that usage is a matter of convention, can change over time, and is sometimes contested

2E55C95E05C94A0A9220D0801F53FFEB.description: LA12.E.36: demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking

D73B0EB7B79541DAB03E29D80C9F17FE.description: LA12.D.35: adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating a command of formal English when indicated or appropriate

8E06A7C68DAF40B9A91481F1D584FC4C.description: LA12.D.34: make strategic use of digital media (e.g., textual, graphical, audio, visual, and interactive elements) in presentations to enhance understanding of findings, reasoning, and evidence and to add interest

DDFB011DC2F047D5B5B511FAA88FCAB4.description: LA12.D.33: present information, findings, and supporting evidence, conveying a clear and distinct perspective, such that listeners can follow the line of reasoning, alternative or opposing perspectives are addressed, and the organization, development, substance, and style are appropriate to purpose, audience, and a range of formal and informal tasks

29736DE4CEB14DF6B4648E5C76D3762A.description: LA12.D.32: evaluate a speaker's point of view, reasoning, and use of evidence and rhetoric, assessing the stance, premises, links among ideas, word choice, points of emphasis, and tone used

D943E7FA7390406CBFA8C39A60D644EE.description: LA12.D.31: integrate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) in order to make informed decisions and solve problems, evaluating the credibility and accuracy of each source and noting any discrepancies among the data

91A65500B4304576B0C0EA6654FBAEC5.description: LA12.D.30.d: respond thoughtfully to diverse perspectives; synthesize comments, claims, and evidence made on all sides of an issue; resolve contradictions when possible; and determine what additional information or research is required to deepen the investigation or complete the task

149D7D9C151247B9890C6B08C6660459.description: LA12.D.30.c: propel conversations by posing and responding to questions that probe reasoning and evidence; ensure a hearing for a full range of positions on a topic or issue; clarify, verify, or challenge ideas and conclusions; and promote divergent and creative perspectives

C7F79B2714784DCCB141D5208D7E0024.description: LA12.D.30.b: work with peers to promote civil, democratic discussions and decision-making, set clear goals and deadlines, and establish individual roles as needed

00F625840E284962A2B201829B2F9A95.description: LA12.D.30.a: come to discussions prepared, having read and researched material under study; explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence from texts and other research on the topic or issue to stimulate a thoughtful, well-reasoned exchange of ideas

36D68D30FB414EE781FF5D584A28F7FE.description: LA12.D.30: initiate and participate effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (e.g., one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grades 11-12 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly and persuasively

B1F0A3B0738E43B5AEEBE9E81468B7C2.description: LA12.C.29: write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of tasks, purposes, and audiences

3EF802686BD14EE5A14774FDD03AF18F.description: LA12.C.28.g: establish connection among observations made in the text in order to support critical analysis and reflection

11F9A7F349BF436194CE80085C20E03E.description: LA12.C.28.f: produce a written reflection to informational texts that reflects on the meaning and value of a piece of writing

25A3FA68ED934C20AB1D84D39AB099BD.description: LA12.C.28.e: produce a written reflection to literature and literary nonfiction that reflects on the meaning and value of a piece of writing

B92611C295C44DADBB51C9E81131FE9D.description: LA12.C.28.d: produce a written critical analysis to informational texts that draws evidence from the text

3C8E2F94F89641CAA3F3F6E8BAF62018.description: LA12.C.28.c: produce a written critical analysis to literature and literary nonfiction that draws evidence from the text

7F097A8BEB23482C83EDD8A904AC83F3.description: LA12.C.28.b: apply grades 11-12 reading standards to informational texts (e.g., delineate and evaluate the reasoning in seminal U.S. texts, including the application of constitutional principles and use of legal reasoning [e.g., in U.S. Supreme Court Case majority opinions and dissents] and the premises, purposes, and arguments in works of public advocacy [e.g., The Federalist, presidential addresses])

0EBDE26A6B304EE1BB0D7B359706A158.description: LA12.C.28.a: apply grades 11-12 reading standards to literature and literary non-fiction (e.g., demonstrate knowledge of 18th, 19th, and early 20th-century foundational works of American literature, including how two or more texts from the same period treat similar themes or topics)

14B46FA19E904BFDA9E28C9D661BDF45.description: LA12.C.28: draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research

220CC4ED0F68455CACAE1FC38038684C.description: LA12.C.27: gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and overreliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation

EC3604F853B64D31AE99E6FBB5588B4F.description: LA12.C.26: conduct short, as well as more sustained, research projects to answer questions (including self-generated questions) or solve problems; narrow or broaden the inquiries when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subjects, demonstrating understanding of the subjects under investigation

05EBB504BEC349A5AB7F346ACCCC1A42.description: LA12.C.25: use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information

724A28DD4FDC44F9ABB682D6937DB23F.description: LA12.C.24: develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience

3EDDF762E39046D497E7D9F949330139.description: LA12.C.23: produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience

37D3A557E55148C4BE3C51EC896B4E7E.description: LA12.C.22.e: provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on what is experienced, observed, or resolved over the course of the narrative

BDFD8E11298E443DBC54403031930B51.description: LA12.C.22.d: use precise words and phrases, telling details, and sensory language to convey a vivid picture of the experiences, events, setting, and/or characters

BAEF8692DBED48D1A7443FFD503E22D7.description: LA12.C.22.c: use a variety of techniques to sequence events so that they build on one another to create a coherent whole and build toward a particular tone and outcome (e.g., a sense of mystery, suspense, growth, or resolution)

915692FECDA94D62897E05AD3A3290A6.description: LA12.C.22.b: use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, reflection, and multiple plot lines, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters

0EA0663A9DC3460A9F75791578A3E606.description: LA12.C.22.a: engage and orient the reader by setting out a problem, situation, or observation and its significance, establishing one or multiple point(s) of view, and introducing a narrator and/or characters; create a smooth progression of experiences or events

7CDDC6EFB7AD4C359A61037D95CB50E2.description: LA12.C.22: write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events, using effective technique, well-chosen details, and well-structured event sequences

8E8BBC9C10B940F5AD35CCD161FAFEC0.description: LA12.C.21.g: provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic)

CD847D4083B84B368364C6D4AC3C67A0.description: LA12.C.21.f: use documents to clarify details or support claims

2F89EB6A4C4040D98CB94C9A1193A5D5.description: LA12.C.21.e: establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing

DD538F79B87C44A69CCBEC04D0DDB81E.description: LA12.C.21.d: use precise language, domain-specific vocabulary, and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic

788073FEA40044F38CD2424D3097C77A.description: LA12.C.21.c: use appropriate and varied transitions and syntax to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships among complex ideas and concepts

BC5CBAF594434464AFFA4CF5A3A0D029.description: LA12.C.21.b: develop the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic

ABC877957E9E417380CBB9D3C8749293.description: LA12.C.21.a: introduce a topic; organize complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

6943BE983BB141E4BEF6C630A798A993.description: LA12.C.21: write informative/explanatory texts to examine and convey complex ideas, concepts, and information clearly and accurately through the effective selection, organization, and analysis of content

2511C97672644A5E92BF51A00E7FAB07.description: LA12.C.20.e: provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument presented

C2F7601C8E2F40DFAC5477919847FAD5.description: LA12.C.20.d: establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing

771E36B76C2A4AB0B85E6250C8C67578.description: LA12.C.20.c: use words, phrases, and clauses as well as varied syntax to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims

2A1D4B99BFBB409584AB2BA25F829D38.description: LA12.C.20.b: develop claim(s) and counterclaims fairly and thoroughly, supplying the most relevant evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both in a manner that anticipates the audience's knowledge level, concerns, values, and possible biases

6258D5B91B3744C990BFE825078FD049.description: LA12.C.20.a: introduce precise, knowledgeable claim(s), establish the significance of the claim(s), distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and create an organization that logically sequences claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence

2ED24BE31B6949299D65C89AAF202693.description: LA12.C.20: write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence

2C6D308EE51B49B688735553B3336D4E.description: LA12.B.19: read and comprehend informational texts at the high end of the grades 11-12 CCR text complexity band independently and proficiently, by the end of grade 12

B056415B0C2645A29713DBAC6830837B.description: LA12.B.18.a: relate a literary work to primary source documents of its literary period or historical setting

BD7B3430686C4DCE9FBD2BD8211CCA69.description: LA12.B.18: analyze foundational documents of historical and literary significance for their themes, purposes, and rhetorical features

C6D1A21F184F408D8E9940FF1EB7DF3C.description: LA12.B.17: delineate and evaluate the reasoning in seminal U.S. texts, including the application of constitutional principles and use of legal reasoning (e.g., in U.S. Supreme Court majority opinions and dissents) and the premises, purposes, and arguments in works of public advocacy (e.g., The Federalist, presidential addresses)

BAEEC5EE109F451C844912F9A842393A.description: LA12.B.16: integrate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in different media or formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively) as well as in words in order to address a question or solve a problem

95E3CDA83CB14FE99420A9794A0D770A.description: LA12.B.15: determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text in which the rhetoric is particularly effective, analyzing how style and content contribute to the power, persuasiveness, or beauty of the text

6127C2A9DBAE41E2B33040B942F2D968.description: LA12.B.14: analyze and evaluate the effectiveness of the structure an author uses in his or her exposition or argument, including whether the structure makes points clear, convincing, and engaging

367D490299E943E8A321A1C6DD612912.description: LA12.B.13: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term or terms over the course of a text (e.g., how Madison defines faction in Federalist No. 10)

6913E2E40688466193AF98DD7ABF1C7F.description: LA12.B.12: analyze a complex set of ideas or sequence of events and explain how specific individuals, ideas, or events interact and develop over the course of the text

A61B80A8C90D4D17BD163155C46222F1.description: LA12.B.11: determine two or more central ideas of a text and analyze their development over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to provide a complex analysis; provide an objective summary of the text

5F688CB348DB4AA499D8CE9A4F154EC6.description: LA12.B.10: cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain

DEB234A8F4284AD789D5B5E48ADE9636.description: LA12.A.9.a: analyze the structures and elements of British and American literature; evaluate each culture's literary influence on the other

C85FA1799DC74341A2B2F2E1DC75677D.description: LA12.A.9: read and comprehend literature and literary nonfiction, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the high end of the grades 11-12 CCR text complexity band independently and proficiently, by the end of grade 12

AFDDB270293A4706A64A2C2B98BF5FF3.description: LA12.A.8: demonstrate knowledge of 18th, 19th, and early 20th-century foundational works (of American literature, British literature, world literature, or multicultural literature), including how two or more texts from the same period treat similar themes or topics

526299934B6C45C38289D10A0F166B45.description: LA12.A.7: analyze multiple interpretations of a story, drama, or poem (e.g., recorded or live production of a play or recorded novel or poetry), evaluating how each version interprets the source text (include at least one play by Shakespeare and one play by an American dramatist)

77F0324E33234683B43FDF92683CCEFB.description: LA12.A.6: analyze a case in which grasping point of view requires distinguishing what is directly stated in a text from what is really meant (e.g., satire, sarcasm, irony, or understatement)

48763F1D8C2A4A59A099E42BC2FE8F3F.description: LA12.A.5: analyze how an author's choices concerning how to structure specific parts of a text (e.g., the choice of where to begin or end a story, the choice to provide a comedic or tragic resolution) contribute to its overall structure and meaning as well as its aesthetic impact

8768D8030FDB43A5AD4CE0CC9F6CBD6F.description: LA12.A.4: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including words with multiple meanings or language that is particularly fresh, engaging, or beautiful (include Shakespeare as well as other authors)

314AB0AC8793449B9CB94D8DA3522B44.description: LA12.A.3: analyze the impact of the author's choices regarding how to develop and relate elements of a story or drama (e.g., where a story is set, how the action is ordered, how the characters are introduced and developed)

16C834C028394DB78DFD065CB4C1B63C.description: LA12.A.2: determine two or more themes or central ideas of a text and analyze their development over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to produce a complex account; provide an objective summary of the text

A3AA7F2E8D7B4E42B3D4D472C5BE1C82.description: LA12.A.1: cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain
